Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships to Enhance Southern New Jersey High-Tech Workforce

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Scholarships to Enhance Southern New Jersey High-Tech Workforce at Rowan University provides scholarships for academically talented students in financial need who are pursing bachelor's degrees in engineering. The project is a multidisciplinary collaboration of the five engineering departments of the College of Engineering at Rowan. The scholarship program supports full-time students who meet financial need and academic merit criteria. A total of 30 scholarships are planned over a five-year period. The program allows Rowan to offer scholarships to directly address an area of national concern: the shortage of US graduates trained in STEM related fields. Scholarships for academically strong engineering students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, have an impact on the number of engineering graduates prepared to help national, regional, and local companies. Talented engineering graduates will directly impact the Southern New Jersey high-tech workforce and help the US to compete and innovate in a global economy.

This effort to enhance the Southern New Jersey high-tech workforce builds on resources available at Rowan University. The project utilizes Rowan's Engineering Learning Community (ELC). The ELC is modeled after research-based best practices for living and learning communities, which have been shown to enhance academic achievement, retention and educational attainment, especially for first year students. The ELC students pursue their academic curriculum with a blended co-curriculum involving a theme, concept, or common subject matter while living together in a reserved part of a residence hall. ELC faculty members and upper-level ELC students provide mentoring. Assessment and evaluation will provide insight into the retention benefits of student scholarships, living and learning communities, in-dorm student mentoring/tutoring, and faculty mentoring/advising. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated widely to the engineering education community and help enlarge the knowledge base regarding attributes and practices of successful scholarship programs of this type.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scholarships to Enhance Southern New Jersey High-Tech Workforce

Federal Award ID: 1457859

2015 to 2020

This NSF S-STEM grant awarded $571,500 in scholarships (93% of total funding) to two cohorts of fifteen students each entering Rowan University (RU) in ‘2015 and ‘2016 (15/16) plus 8 Junior/Senior replacements for a total of 38 students. Scholarships were $5,000 per student per year. Eight students (21%) left the program: four remained at RU in other majors while the others transferred to other institutions or joined the Navy. The 15/16 cohorts participated in the Rowan Engineering Living-Learning Community (ELC) in which first-year engineering students live together, take common classes, and participate in seminars and extracurricular activities. The ELC has operated since ‘09. Starting in ‘2016, RU pays select ELC alumni to mentor/tutor ELC students and lead seminars. The ELC expanded from 20 to 133 students and increased seminar frequency. The expansion allows all interested students to join.

Given that the 15/16 cohorts are graduated or in the spring semester of their fifth and fourth years, respectively, the retention/graduation rates shown in Table 1 are expected to result in very similar 6-year graduation rates. ELC students’ retention/graduation rates are higher than non-ELC students. The high retention/graduation of the NSF-S-STEM scholarship students is notable, given that they all have significant financial need and 61 % were from underrepresented groups in engineering.

Table 1 Rowan University (RU) engineering retention (all engineering students entering Fall '15 or '16)

2015 & 2016 Engineering Cohorts

Number Entering

% Retained at or Graduated from RU as of Spring ‘20

All Majors

STEM

Engineering

Non-ELC

508

83

75

66

ELC

198

87

82

76

NSF S-STEM

38

89

82

79

 

Intellectual Merit: The grant advanced the understanding of how living and learning communities ease the transition to college. Guidelines for growing LLCs were published in a refereed journal article.

Broader Impacts: The grant provided financial support to 36 STEM undergraduates at Rowan University (RU) and living and learning community support to 547.


Last Modified: 06/04/2020
Modified by: Jess W Everett
